newsitem.title: BELGIUM: Waigel says won't support costly EU jobs schemes.
newsitem.headline: Waigel says won't support costly EU jobs schemes.

text.p: German Finance Minister Theo Waigel said on Monday Bonn welcomes greater coordination among European countries on labour policies, but it would not support costly jobs-creation schemes.
The recently elected leftist French government has stressed the need for greater emphasis on jobs in the run-up to European monetary union (EMU).

"We welcome more intensive coordination of jobs policies, but we will not transfer additional authority to the European Union, especially for costly programmes," Waigel said at a meeting of European finance ministers.

Such coordination should rest on a review of best practices in the various countries, he said. The ministers are due to discuss policies on fighting high unemployment, Europe's most pressing economic problem, at a special summit in November.
Waigel said EMU would change the policy landscape by eliminating the buffer of flexible exchange rates, demanding that participating countries have greater flexibility in their labour policies.

Intensive discussion is still needed on coordination of economic policies among the prospective EMU member states, leading to a final approval of the points resolved at the Amsterdam summit last month, he said.
